Methods used to spatially locate geological features and exploration, mining and related infrastructure sites. These can be either features directly observed in the field (e.g. site/outcrop descriptions, structural readings, etc.) or obtained from legacy and current documents/datasets (e.g. airphotos, maps, previously published reports, exploration reports, etc.). Each location method has a spatial accuracy that indicates an estimate of the approximate error in the location. Captured geographical locations for geological or mining features are expressed as a set of coordinates (latitude and longitude degrees), with or without an elevation above or below sea level.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Geographical location acquired with a Differential Global Positioning System (DGPS), i.e. a receiver instrument that utilises a network of fixed-position, ground-based reference stations that calculate the difference between their highly accurate known position and their less accurate satellite-derived position, thereby increasing the accuracy compared to a Global Positioning System that only utilises satellite stations. Accuracy varies from 15 m to a few centimetres, but it is commonly within 1 m. Captured using the World Geodetic System 1984 or, in Australia, the Geocentric Datum of Australia 1994.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Used by GSWA to capture locations of geological observations or exploration/mining/infrastructure sites.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Geographical location acquired with a Differential Global Positioning System (DGPS), i.e. a receiver instrument that utilises a network of fixed-position, ground-based reference stations that calculate the difference between their highly accurate known position and their less accurate satellite-derived position, thereby increasing the accuracy compared to a Global Positioning System that only utilises satellite stations. Accuracy varies from 15 m to a few centimetres, but it is commonly within 1 m. Captured using the World Geodetic System 1984 or, in Australia, the Geocentric Datum of Australia 1994.
